Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Mechanisms and Evolution of Social Recognition in Rocket Frogs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Humans are not the only animals that recognize familiar individuals. In fact, many animals can recognize their social partners. However, we still know little about the sensory and learning processes by which animals come to recognize familiar individuals and how this behavior evolves. This project uses playback experiments in the wild to compare the processes by which frogs learn to recognize their neighbors. By comparing the behavior of two closely-related frog species that differ in this ability but share a recent evolutionary ancestor, the project will also test how recognition behavior evolved. This project will provide an international experience for undergraduate students, and create materials for both a course at the University of Minnesota and a public museum exhibit at Kaieteur National Park in Guyana.

Male Golden Rocket Frogs recognize and respond less aggressively to the calls of familiar territorial neighbors, while male Kai Rocket Frogs show no evidence of recognition. This project uses habituation-discrimination experiments with natural and synthetic calls to compare the perceptual basis of neighbor recognition in these two species. In the first experiment, the ability of males of both species to discriminate between the calls of different individuals will be examined to test the hypothesis that neighbor recognition evolves by narrowing the specificity of learned social categories. In the second experiment, synthetic calls, in which acoustic properties can be manipulated independently, will be used to test the hypothesis that male golden rocket frogs discriminate between the calls of different individuals using the most reliable acoustic cues of identity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Like humans, many non-human animals recognize familiar individuals, allowing them to treat individuals differently based on experience and established relationships. This ability, termed “social recognition”, underlies many important behaviors such as respecting dominance hierarchies in group-living primates, or feeding offspring in birds that live in colonies and risk mistakenly caring for un-related young. Biologists have documented many examples of social recognition in different taxonomic groups, but we still know very little about how animals recognize familiar individuals and how this complex behavior has evolved.

To understand the mechanisms and evolution of social recognition, we exploited a unique situation of two closely related species of frogs that differ in a common form of social recognition. Male golden rocket frogs defend territories where they vocalize and show a form of social recognition in which they recognize the calls of their territory neighbors. This allows them to treat established neighbors with less aggression than strangers, who may be looking to take over their defended resources. In contrast, male Kai rocket frogs are equally aggressive to the calls of neighbors and strangers. Previous analyses showed that the calls of these two species have similar amounts of individual variation, rejecting the hypothesis that the calls of golden rocket frogs have evolved to signal individual identity. Instead, the calls of both species show individual variation and are best described as “identity cues”, similar to human finger prints which can be used to identify individuals but have not evolved for that purpose. Therefore, this project aimed to understand how golden rocket frogs have evolved to use these identity cues to recognize neighbors.

The first aim of this project asked whether natural selection has shaped the cognitive mechanisms involved in learning and remembering the calls of familiar individuals. We used habituation-discrimination experiments to examine the specificity of learning in both species; we first simulated the arrival of a new neighbor during the habituation phase, and then changed the calls during the subsequent discrimination phase to see if males recognized the new calls as being produced by a different individual. Both species responded aggressively to these calls and both eventually habituated, but only golden rocket frogs showed renewed territorial aggression upon hearing the calls of a different individual during the discrimination phase. The results of this experiment showed that the key difference between these two species that allows golden rocket frogs to learn the to recognize neighbors is the specificity of learning through habituation. These results therefore confirmed that social recognition in golden rocket frogs has evolved in response to selection on the cognitive mechanisms of learning and discrimination.

The second aim of this project was to determine how golden rocket frogs discriminate individual differences in calls. We used the same habituation-discrimination experimental procedure but used synthetically generated calls, allowing use to manipulate acoustic properties of these during the experiment. We found that males could discriminate between calls that differed only in the temporal properties of the pulses within a call (i.e., the duration of pulses and the interval between consecutive pulses). We found that they only discriminate between calls that exceed a threshold difference of about 12% in these acoustic properties, demonstrating that although calls vary continuously, male golden rocket frogs group this continuous variation into discrete categories. These threshold decision rules allow them to accommodate some natural within-individual variation in calls but to still recognize when a call is different enough that is likely being produced by a different individual. This experiment therefore uncovered the perceptual basis of an independently evolved social recognition system.

The research made possible by this funding advanced our understanding of social recognition and how evolution shapes communication systems. By showing that the evolution of social recognition was enabled by evolutionary changes in perception and cognition, we demonstrated that selection imposed by the social environment can drive cognitive evolution. These results also have implications to our understanding of human cognition, which is thought to have evolved, in part, due to the demands of recognizing individuals and managing social relationships.

Additionally, this project yielded several impacts beyond the scientific community. This project provided important research training to one graduate students, and three young aspiring scientists, two of which are from groups that are currently underrepresented in academic science. The results of this research are also being disseminated to a broad international audience through the tours and a museum exhibit at Kaieteur National Park in Guyana. Golden rocket frogs are a charismatic species of important cultural and mythological significance to the local Patomona Amerindian tribe, and Amerindian rangers who were part of this field research now incorporate details of the interesting behaviors of these frogs into the tours they give at the park.
